awd_titl_txt: New England Water Treatment Training (NEWTT) Program
awd_abstract_narration:
The New England Water Treatment Training Program (NEWTT) will recruit and educate community college students for careers in water treatment and wastewater treatment. With input from academic, industrial and government partners, NEWTT will produce a model curriculum and certificate program that can be delivered in both onsite and online formats, giving students the flexibility to balance career development with their lives. NEWTT will disseminate its model to neighboring institutions through equipment loans and consulting, leading the New England region in modernizing and growing its technical workforce. With much of the existing water treatment and wastewater treatment workforce preparing to retire by the year 2020, NEWTT will help ensure this region of the country is prepared to deal with emerging issues surrounding access to clean water.  

The goals of this project are to recruit and prepare students for careers in water and wastewater treatment. With input from its partners and an industrial advisory board, NEWTT will conduct a Developing a Curriculum (DACUM) workshop to ensure its program is aligned with industry and community needs, and the program prepares students with the proper knowledge and skills to enter the regional workforce. The use of hybrid instructional methods will ensure NEWTT reaches students in urban, suburban, and rural areas. NEWTT will use a prior learning assessment tool to link students' non-credit experiences and certifications to germane academic credit. Project evaluation will focus on the progress of developing the program and student performance indicators such as enrollment, success, and retention. The participation of community colleges from throughout the New England region will assure the program deliverables have broad application and impact, and will serve as a model as other institutions adopt NEWTT's program.

por.por_cntn:
Clean water is essential for all life. In the United States we take for granted that we can turn on a faucet and safe drinking water flows from it. There are people working around the clock to ensure that the water we drink and discharge into the environment ins meets national standards. Unfortunately, there is a critical shortage of these workers nationwide.  As current workers retire there aren?t enough qualified workers to replace them. The New England Water Treatment Training (NEWTT) Project was designed to help address this problem.

The Goals of the New England Water Treatment Training Project were:

1. Build on BCC?s 18 years of water training experience to develop a New England Regional Water Technologies Curriculum Framework that maps skill, knowledge and licensing requirements needed to prepare for careers in two major areas of water management: 1) Drinking Water Operations; 2) Wastewater Treatment Operations 

2. Design an educational pathway and hybrid (online and onsite) curriculum composed of two certificate options (one for each sector area) that articulate with associate degrees aligned with the NEWTT Curriculum Framework (activity 1). Employ methods that promote engagement such as industry scenarios

3. Build capacity to increase the supply of qualified water technicians throughout New England and expand participation of groups under-represented in STEM studies including women, people of color, Veterans and displaced workers. 

4. Conduct formative and summative evaluation activities to determine project outcomes

The New England Water Treatment Training (NEWTT) Project worked with water industry representatives from throughout New England on a DACUM (Developing a Curriculum) to guide the development of training programs to prepare the next generation of water industry employees.  We developed 5 new courses to enhance our current Associate Degree in Engineering Technology / Environmental Technology and created two new certificates, the Drinking Water Quality Professional/Technician Certificate and the Clean Water Quality Professional/ Technician Certificate.  We developed hybrid courses and a schedule which required students to only come to school one morning or afternoon per week.  Also, during COVID restriction periods, we developed fully online courses which were provided free to students.  This resulted in students from the other New England states taking our classes.  Our Drinking Water training courses have also been approved by the Massachusetts Board of Certification of Drinking Water Operators, which allows students to sit for Massachusetts Certification Examinations. To accelerate the completion of a certificate or degree, students to used their state certification credentials to get credit for courses that were designed to prepare them for obtaining those credentials through our Credit for Prior Learning office.  

 We greatly enhanced the capabilities of our Blue Center for Water Technologies, which was established under a Presidential Fellowship in 2014. A model functioning drinking water treatment plant was constructed, and a wastewater treatment plants was developed from existing aquaculture equipment. The analytical capabilities were greatly increased.  We added pump and flow meter training facilities, split working valves, and additional groundwater simulators and jar testing gang stirrers.

We increased participation of underrepresented populations through collaborations with our Advising Office and a grant with our Adult Basic Education program from the Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education, Massachusetts Skills Training Education Program, called the Bridge to Clean Water Program. This included participation  of women, people of color, veterans and displaced workers.

Students successfully completing our programs have passed certification examinations and quickly found employment.  Associate degree students were required to do an internship, which generally lead to employment. Through our Advisory Board, we have strong relationships with our water industry partners, as well as regulatory and operator organizations.

Our program also aimed to provide a pathway for students to move from high school to college, and on to employment. We have worked at bringing area high schools to the Blue Center for Water Technologies for training in various areas of water treatment and to acquaint them with our programs. This activity was on hold during the COVID restriction period. We served on several school advisory boards. We provided professional development for college and high school faculty, as well as non-academic trainers, through our week-long Train-the-Trainer Programs. We worked with other community colleges and high schools to develop, or enhance, their water training programs. Our Equipment Lending Lab has allowed high schools, colleges, and training organizations to use of our equipment when available.

Evaluations conducted throughout the course of the grant period have highlighted our successes and challenges through review of our accomplishments and interviews from participants and industrial representatives.  Students have commented on the breadth of preparation they have received, as well as the support to help them succeed. One operator organization had labelled us the best training program in the state.
